title: Boys’ water polo routed by Gunn for the second time
content: [caption id="attachment_123652" align="alignleft" width="684"] Paly senior field player Eric Maser scores on a volley from the left side of the pool in the 3rd quarter to tie the game against the Titans on Tuesday at Gunn. Despite a hard fought effort, the Vikings fell against Gunn, bringing the Vikings to .500 on the season. Photo by Ethan Kao.[/caption] The Palo Alto High School boys’ water polo team (8-8, 5-2) suffered a loss for the second time by the Gunn High School Titans this season (6-3, 6-0) this season by a score of 8-5 on Tuesday at Gunn. This loss marks the second De Anza League loss for Paly, with both losses coming against Gunn. Although junior field player Jack Andersen and several senior field players gave their best efforts, the Vikings fell short to the overpowering Titans who led the Vikings for the majority of the game. After Andersen’s first goal early in the game, the Titans scored four straight. However, the Vikings persevered and continued to battle for the entire length of the game, unlike their last match against Gunn, according to Paly senior field player Tommy Smale. “I don’t like losing to Gunn at all, but we have gotten better since the first game,” Smale said. “Last game, we died in the second quarter. But this time we fought to the fourth quarter.” Although Anderson credited his goals to clear communication and constant activity, he said the team could have fared better in those key areas. “We were on and off,” Andersen said. “We scored when we had teamwork. Both of the times I scored, it was off drives created through my teammates moving. As a result, I could get open because the defense had to move, and I took advantage of that. We need to work on having that great movement throughout the entire game. We didn’t have that movement the whole time, especially the third quarter.” Goalkeeper Ben Rapperport also had his own perspective to offer on what type of improvements the team can make. “We need to consistently get back on defense and make our shots, and if we do that, we can limit the goals we let in and win our games against Gunn,” Rapperport said. In addition to Andersen’s two goals, senior field players Alex Beaudry, Eric Maser and Andrew Jozefov each scored a goal, in that respective order. With these improvements regarding team movement and defense, Andersen said the team can bounce back with a win. The Vikings will play their next game at 3 p.m. on Wednesday at Saint Francis High School.
excerpt: School boys’ water polo team (8-8, 5-2) suffered a loss for the second time by the Gunn High School Titans this season (6-3, 6-0) this season by a score of 8-5 on Tuesday at Gunn.
author: Sam Lee

title: Walk and Roll Day in numbers
content: Palo Alto High School students show their support for going green this morning as they bike, rollerblade, skateboard and walk onto campus participating in the annual Walk & Roll Day tradition. Walk & Roll Day is an annual event which encourages eco-friendly and physically active methods of commuting to school, according to Palo Alto Unified School District’s website. In previous years, parent volunteers handed out candy to those who walked or rolled to school. However, due to the new school policy banning the distribution of candy on campus, students received colorful 'Go Green!' stickers instead. Despite the change, Walk & Roll Day was still a hit with hundreds of students opting to take the "green" route to school.
excerpt: Palo Alto High School students participated in the annual Walk & Roll day this morning through by riding their bikes, rollerblading, skateboarding or walking to school.
author: Aisha Chabane

title: Performing Arts Center formally introduced
content: The highly anticipated Performing Arts Center is officially open for use by the Paly community after a grand opening Saturday, after a large crowd of Palo Alto teachers, parents, students and community members came for a celebratory gala. To open the four-hour ceremony, instrumental music teacher Jeff WIllner and the Paly Symphonic Band took the stage, playing “Magic To Do” from "Pippin", and finishing with the Paly fight song, which raised a roar from those in attendance, many of whom were Paly alumni. Principal Kim Diorio explained the importance of the building, and what it will bring to the community. “It’s so amazing that we now have this humungous stage," Diorio said. "Our [performing arts] program has grown over the last several years, so it [opening of PAC] good timing." Following Diorio’s speech, the Theater 3 and 4 honors classes used the state-of-the-art lighting and control center to put on a psychedelic and colorful display, while Willner’s orchestra and band played below the stage in the Orchestra pit. “I was thrilled to be a part of the new theater’s big opening, because many people put in hard work to get it done," said Arman Chalwa, a Theater 3 student. "I was really nervous because I felt like we had to do an excellent job introducing this building, but once I walked on stage I forgot all about my nerves." Madrigals, an advanced and selective vocal group, began its performance on the second level of the of the PAC, and strode through the theatre allowing the audience to view and capture the spirit of the program. The Madrigals enchanted the crowd with their extravagant clothing and marvelous tones. This performance also marked the beginning of the 50th year of the program. “The Gala was such a mind-blowing experience," said senior member of the Madrigal program Joao-Gabriel Carvalho De Pina. "To see all of the performing arts programs come together was amazing and unforgettable. You don’t get to see an event like this everyday and I’m so honored and so glad I was a part of it." Paly graduate and Broadway performer Alex Nee showcased his talents in a duet with senior Soo Kim and a solo acoustic guitar performance. Following the orchestra’s initial performance, Paly choir groups filled the rafters behind the last line of cellos and violas, combining for a masterful performance, where vocals, instruments and technological lighting exhibited the potential of the venue. Almost interactive, the choir groups moved into the isles of the theatre, and then proceeded to captivate the crowd with the hymn “Gloria.” The grand finale brought together all of the ensembles as members of choir, orchestra, jazz band and theatre were brought together to perform multiple songs and broadway numbers, most notably “For Good” and “Defying Gravity” from the musical "Wicked." Palo Alto native Rob Minkoff, director of "The Lion King," introduced the final song, a Lion King Medley, which included the “Circle of Life.” As the crowd sang along, choir, orchestra, theater and band members provided the background vocals and music. Minkoff showed that he is much more than a Hollywood director, singing the lead part for a medley of songs from "The Lion King." Architect Erwin Lee worked hard with a committee of Paly teachers and administrators to model the PAC after Spanish mission style architecture, similar to that of the Tower Building, bringing a modern yet traditional aspect to the campus. The next PAC event will feature "The Important of Being Earnest," the upcoming fall play on Friday, Nov 4.
excerpt: The highly anticipated Performing Arts Center is officially open for use by the Paly community after a grand opening Saturday, after a large crowd of Palo Alto teachers, parents, students and community members came for a celebratory gala.

title: Tuesday Tunes: Gabe Cohen
content:
[caption id="attachment_123371" align="aligncenter" width="548"] Junior Gabe Cohen strums his guitar during a summer music camp he attended last year. Photo: Maoz Wolff[/caption] The Paly Voice sat down with drummer and guitarist junior Gabe Cohen to talk about his musical background, band experience and goals for the future. He has been an advocate for positive change at our school and the community by joining the Social Justice Pathway in his sophomore year. As reported by Cohen, he was an energetic child earning him the nickname "the rocket." He started his music career when he learned the drums in second grade because he wanted a way to let out all of his energy.

“What really brought me into music was the movie 'School of Rock,' with Jack Black," Cohen said. "That movie really inspired me to play and learn music and it showed me how beneficial music can be to your soul.”

According to Cohen, music has been an outlet and a place where he can be himself. He added that as he gets older, his music tastes change and are always growing.

“I really like the emotion in music," Cohen said. "I like when you can actually feel what the artist is feeling through music. That’s why I like punk music, because it’s angry, it’s loud, it’s pure emotion. I also like folk music, where there is nothing else in it except the emotion.”

Cohen is part of multiple bands and has different goals for each of them. One is the School of Rock, which is a national after school program that allows teenagers to play rock music in a band and creates an open community for music lovers.

Cohen participates in the Palo Alto program but there is also a program located in San Jose. He also has bands that are just for fun with friends, where they just relax and jam out without any stress or pressure.

“I think my favorite gig I’ve ever played in was last summer when I threw a concert in my basement," Cohen said. "A lot of people came. That was a really cool experience for me because it was one of the first times I planned everything for myself and it really was an amazing experience.”

Below is Cohen's Spotify playlist where he picked some of his favorite songs.

title: Preview: Spirit Week Themes
content: [caption id="attachment_43149" align="alignnone" width="614"] The Class of 2015 cheers on its peers during the sophomore spirit dance. [Photo: Cathy Rong][/caption] Can the firefighting Class of 2019 extinguish the junior fighting spirit? Will the freshman earn their stripes? Or will it be "Game Over" for everyone? With Spirit Week just around the corner, each Palo Alto High School class is eagerly preparing for the most passionate week of the school year. As always, the freshmen, sophomores, juniors and seniors will be represented by their class colors: orange, red, yellow and green, respectively. For its last Spirit Week at Paly, the senior Class of 2017 has gone with the theme of “Game Over.” According to senior Tanner Newell, the Class of 2017 has the potential to do better than previous years. “I think a lot of people are much more engaged this year so we should do better than we’ve ever done before,” Newell said. After much deliberation, the junior class  decided on "boxing" as its theme. There was a bit of controversy over choosing boxing as the theme, as the class originally voted for a different idea. According to junior Sabrina Hall, Spirit Week should be about class unity, not infighting. “I think that the people sort of forgot what Spirit Week is supposed to be about,” Hall said. “It's being united as one grade and all just enjoying this week as a sign of just love for the school and love for the class.” The members of the Class of 2019 are coming into Spirit Week with more confidence than last year and are planning to redeem themselves after coming last during their freshman year with the theme of “firefighters.” “I think the theme is pretty nice," sophomore Paul Shand said. "I think freshmen are going to come last, but I hope we do great.” The freshman class  will be kicking off its first Spirit Week with the theme, “Eye of the Tiger.” Freshman Sarah O’Riordan is excited for the theme. “The freshman theme is so awesome this year,” O'Riordan said. “I can’t wait to see how everyone looks during Spirit Week.”
excerpt: Can the firefighting Class of 2019 extinguish the junior fighting spirit? Will the freshman earn their stripes? Or will it be "Game Over" for everyone?

title: Guide to school board elections: Melissa Baten Caswell
content: [caption id="attachment_122810" align="alignleft" width="436"] Melissa Baten Caswell, who has completed two terms on the school board, acknowledged areas of improvement and strengths of the current school board during the school board forum on Sept. 20 at the Mitchell Park Community Center. Photo: Zahra Muzaffar[/caption] The Paly Voice attended the first school board forum hosting all five candidates for the upcoming election. Each candidate hoped to distinguish him or herself from the group, discussing bold ideas while acknowledging problems faced by the district. Read on to take an in-depth look at the various candidates and their platforms. Melissa Baten Caswell, a current school board member, is running for her third term. Caswell has previously served as board president and has experience serving on various school specific PTA councils. At the school board election forum on Sept. 20 at the Mitchell Park Community center, Caswell said she believes in the importance of making sure all Palo Alto Unified School District students are lifelong learners with skills that are relevant in the current and future economy. “We have to make sure every single student is engaged in the classroom and supported, in academics and social emotional health,” Caswell said. “Promote life long learners [that are] engaged in their education. We need to be looking at the whole child, looking at every single student.” In addition, Caswell recounted the various improvements and new additions to curriculum that have taken place during her time on the school board. She noted that an area of improvement is allowing teachers to lead these breakthroughs by providing adequate resources and opportunities. “We have added flipped classrooms, blended learning, pathways [and] we put in a program with 200 students doing research projects,” Caswell said. “I do think one action is to help our teachers with innovative ideas and flushing them out. Give them some time. If we don't give teachers time to focus on innovative ideas they can't do it. Help teachers invest in choice.” Caswell provided further explanations for her past stance against the opening of a new elementary school by noting the amount of classrooms that aren’t used for core classes. “There has been declining enrollment for 5-6 years, it's expensive to have a school,” Caswell said.  “Twenty six classrooms are not being used as primary classrooms in elementary schools." She addressed student-teacher ratios by stating that its importance varies based on the type of class and the teaching style of the instructor. “The quality of the teacher preempts everything,” Caswell said. “I think it would be a good idea for us to have ranges for class size. When we talk about averages it's across the school or department, I think putting hard caps would be difficult.” Caswell highlighted that the district’s previous homework policy should be reevaluated. As it is currently written the board has set a limit on the amount of hours a student should be spending per week on homework, however she stated that the policy isn’t always applicable to all classes or students. “The homework policy is really tough, I think we have some thinking to do about what really should be the policy,” Caswell said. “I don't think a hard cap on minutes works in an environment where students complete work differently. Results have not been brought back to the board and It's hard for teachers to use the policy as it currently is.” Mental health and wellness has always been a vital topic in the Palo Alto community, and Caswell expressed her search for an improved system of assistance while acknowledging the district’s limitations. “Our mission is education of our students and we will never be excellent mental health service providers,” Caswell said. “I look for new models in our community, I am looking to Stanford and other experts. This is a regional issue, state issue and we should work together with our colleagues in the city and state wide.” In light of recent events at Palo Alto High School, student journalists brought to light questions regarding the behavioral conduct among students and teachers. Caswell repeatedly emphasized the importance of an accessible and understandable policy. “It [sexual assault] is incredibly serious and we need to make sure what policy is written down is clear and understandable,” Caswell said. “If everyone understands expectations then it's clear when they've been crossed. It is important that our teachers can be supportive of our students.” Take a look at an introduction to the other candidates and their stances on various issues currently faced by the community, as expressed during the forum. Overview of all candidates Jay Blas Jacob Cabrera Todd Collins Jennifer DiBrienza Heidi Emberling

title: Guide to school board elections: Jay Blas Jacob Cabrera
content: [caption id="attachment_122797" align="alignright" width="384"] Jacob Cabrera is one of five candidates running for school board. At the school board election forum on Sept. 20 at the Mitchell Park Community Center, he explained his thoughts on current issues and innovations relating to education in Palo Alto. Photo: Zahra Muzaffar[/caption] The Paly Voice attended the first school board forum hosting all five candidates for the upcoming election. Each candidate hoped to distinguish him or herself from the group, discussing bold ideas while acknowledging problems faced by the district. Read on to take an in-depth look at the various candidates and their platforms. Jay Blas Jacob Cabrera, a community organizer, is one of five candidates for the upcoming school board election. Having unsuccessfully run for the Board of Education in the 2014 election, Cabrera hopes to gain support for his unique propositions. At the school board election forum on Sept. 20 at the Mitchell Park Community Center, he emphasized the need for equipping all students with 21st century skills that allow them to reach their full potential. Cabrera said he hopes to engage youth in civic matters by lowering the voting age to 15. He expressed the need for relevant life skills and aims to create an educational system that caters to the unique qualities of each individual student. “Schools should be cultural epicenters of innovation,” Cabrera said. “We should be empowering our youth, and getting youth engaged in society early, transforming the way they interact.” Cabrera’s innovative ideas include integration between elementary and secondary schools. In addition, he says he believes core class sizes ideally should not exceed 20 students. “Integration between elementary, middle and high schools of multiple different ages and types of education in the same space is healthy and a new dynamic,” Cabrera said. “Class size matters a lot, it should be under 20 students. University style lectures in the high schools where they then break out into smaller groups could be effective.” Though he said he wishes to reduce class sizes overall, Cabrera strayed away from providing a hard cap on the number of students enrolled in a class. Over the past few years student complaints have increased in regards to the amount of homework assigned at the secondary level. In addition parents and students have brought up the issue of "test stacking". Many students have multiple tests in core subjects on the same day and sitting through two or three consecutive 90 minute blocks of testing can be grueling. Cabrera believes that to solve the homework and test staking problem in the school district, it is necessary to have at least one year of research and collection of data on the specific topics mentioned above. "I wouldn't be comfortable [discussing solutions] until talking to students and teachers,” Cabrera said. “My interaction with students has been that homework is increasing, and we should reduce in general the amount of homework for free time with families.” According to Cabrera, although mental health is one of the most prominent issues in the community, there is yet to be a solution. “We need to be preemptively active in solving our issues, we need to recognize that we don't have the solutions,” Cabrera said. “The real issues are the societal pressures.” Take a look at an introduction to the other candidates and their stances on various issues currently faced by the community, as expressed during the forum. title: School board candidates vie for three opening seats
content: [caption id="attachment_122786" align="alignnone" width="594"] All five Palo Alto Board of Education candidates pose for a photo together while preparing for the first forum of the 2016 election cycle on Sept. 20. The forum took place at the Mitchell Community Center and was live streamed by Palo Alto Online. Photo: Zahra Muzaffar[/caption] With less than 40 days remaining until election day on Nov. 8, five candidates for the Palo Alto school board are campaigning in hopes of gaining one of the three opening seats. Two of the five candidates are running for re-election — Heidi Emberling and Melissa Baten Caswell — while the other three candidates include Jay Cabrera, Todd Collins and Jennifer DiBrienza. The third elected member will replace Camille Townsend, a board member since 2008. The newly elected members will serve on the school board for the next four years. As the community currently faces multi-faceted issues, including the budget deficit, the conduct of teachers on campus and the continued anticipation over the coming Epi-Aid final report, candidates will play a major role in decisions that will affect the Palo Alto Unified School District for years to come. Each candidate brings a unique set of experiences from his or her professional life. Emberling serves as the current president of the school board and if elected would be returning for her second term in office. She also serves as a teacher and parent educator at Parents Place, an early child development and learning resource center. Caswell, the most experienced of the group, would be returning for her third term. She has previously served as board president and is experienced in strategy, finance and high tech marketing. Collins and Dibrienza have experience working closely with the district, while Cabrera is a Gunn High School alumnus. Collins is a private investor and has served on the citizens’ oversight committee of a school bond program and the school board’s Enrollment Management Advisory Committee over the 2015-16 school year. Dibrienza was a teacher and staff developer for primary education before switching to become an educational consultant and has served on Ohlone Elementary School’s site council. Cabrera, a community organizer, currently works as chief executive officer of Unity Network. According to its website, Unity Network is a nonprofit that aims to solve 21st century problems through innovative methods. [caption id="attachment_122812" align="alignright" width="451"] Student journalists, Matthew Hamilton from Gunn High School's Oracle, and Kai Oda from Palo Alto High School's The Campanile, take part in asking the school board candidates questions. Photo: Daniel Li[/caption] All five school board candidates gathered at the Mitchell Park Community Center for a forum hosted by Palo Alto Online. Two high school journalists, Matthew Hamilton, Gunn Oracle’s co-managing editor, and Kai Oda, co-editor-in-chief of Palo Alto High School's The Campanile, moderated the second half of the forum. The two asked the candidates questions ranging from ensuring equity at the two high schools to to supporting the continuation of teacher evaluations at the end of the semester. Still not sure who to vote for? Take a look at an introduction to each candidate and their stances on various issues currently faced by the community, as expressed during the forum. title: Admin calls for safety reform after bike accident
content: [caption id="attachment_123296" align="alignnone" width="541"] Police block the intersection of Churchill Ave. and Castilleja Ave. where a car struck a Palo Alto High School student this morning. According to Principal Kim Diorio, further accidents may occur unless safety precautions are added to the dangerous intersection. "I would love to say that it [the accident] would be the last time but until we get more measures in place, who knows," Diorio said. Photo: Rachel Code.[/caption]Principal Kim Diorio is renewing her call for safety improvements at a key intersection after a driver struck a Palo Alto High School student while she biked to school at the intersection of Churchill Ave. and Castilleja Ave. this morning. According to Principal Kim Diorio, the student did not suffer any severe injuries, but EMTs took her to the hospital and she is expected to make a swift recovery. "She was then transported to the hospital, and it sounds like she is going to be ok," Diorio said. "The EMTs said that they wanted to transport her to the hospital just to make sure that everything was ok." Diorio said the driver remained with the student until paramedics and police arrived. "The driver of the vehicle stayed on scene and police and paramedics were called," Diorio said. "Police helped block Churchill while the Emergency Medical Technicians responded to the student." According to Diorio, she has always deemed the intersection unsafe. "I often feel like it's [the intersection] just an accident waiting to happen given the number of bikes crossing and the people in a rush," Diorio said. To increase the safety of students at the Churchill crossing, Diorio said the placement of a crossing guard next to the intersection will help keep drivers alert and prevent further accidents. "I feel really strongly that we should have a crossing guard at the Churchill and Castilleja intersection," Diorio said. "I've asked for the district to help provide the funding for that." Despite the frequent request from Diorio, the city has not yet come to a decision. Diorio said that the city is working on making the intersection safer. "I know the city has done more signage and they're looking at the bike lane and that light, but a crossing guard would be my hope," Diorio said.
excerpt: Principal Kim Diorio is renewing her call for safety improvements at a key intersection after a driver struck a Palo Alto High School student while she biked to school at the intersection of Churchill Ave. and Castilleja Ave. this morning.
author: Noah Yuen

title: Featured Athlete: Runner Kent Slaney
content: Imagine: A six-year-old Kent Slaney dashes through the Escondido Elementary School playground, leaving his playmates in the dust. Breezing through the dreaded mile runs in P.E., and finishing just in time for a nap and his favorite Jamba Juice. Flash to today, and Slaney is a senior and key member of both the Palo Alto High School cross country and track and field teams, amazes his community and consistently breaks personal and course records. According to Slaney, he discovered running at a very young age, but credits his original involvement in the sport to Jamba Juice gift cards. "I started running with Escondido jogging club," Slaney said. "They were giving out Jamba Juice gifts cards, so I wanted one of those. I then started my first race, and things kept going from there." According to Slaney, no one in his family had ever been runner, and his sudden growing interest in running gave his parents the idea of signing him up for his first race. He hasn't looked back since. "My parents did that first race with me, but after that I was on my own and just enjoyed running." Slaney said. "I did it whenever I could." As a freshman, Kent Slaney broke three season records, landing him in the top 50 running times. As a sophomore, he broke two, and another in junior year at the Lowell invitational. If one were to look at his stats, they would see consistent broken personal records at nearly every cross country meet. Cross country has a unique point system. The five fastest runners from each team to cross the finish line receive the points that correspond to their place. The first place runner receives one point, the second place runner two, and so on. The team receiving the lowest score wins, according to Capo Valley's Cross Country guide. Kent recounts the latest invitational and remarks on the teams performance as a whole. "So far it's been pretty spectacular, both as a team and individually," Slaney said. "At [the] Lowell [Invitational] we did great as a team. We got 41 points, and the next best team got 91. Also, in our first scrimmage with Gunn [High School], I broke a course record by 11 seconds. Looks like it's going to be a really great season," Slaney said. Each meet has its own set of records from past competitors. Slaney broke a course record for a meet against Gunn, with a time of 10:13 on a 2.2 mile course. Most recently, he has bested his past miles times with his new personal record of 4 minutes and 16.63 seconds, according to his CA Cross Country Profile. But Slaney is more than just a cross country star; he aspires to pursue a career in STEM. "I want to major in computer science or electrical engineering," Slaney said. "I enjoy programming a lot; I'd enjoy going into that field. I'm also looking into recruitment options, and have been balancing running with academics." Kent encourages everyone to give running a try. "Running is something that when you put your effort into it, you enjoy it so much. You go out with all the problems in the world, and come back and none of them will matter."
excerpt: Imagine: A six-year-old Kent Slaney dashes through the Escondido Elementary School playground, leaving his playmates in the dust. Flash to today, Slaney is a key member of both the Palo Alto High School cross country and track and field teams. He amazes his community and consistently breaks personal and course records.
